### Exercises 

1. A graduating senior  has signed up for three job interviews. She intends to categorize each one as being
either a “success” (s) or a “failure” (f) depending on whether it leads to a site visit.

a. Write the appropriate sample space $S$.

b. What outcomes are in the event $E$: second success occurs on third visit?


2. Suppose you watch a traffic intersection for $n$ days. Let $E_i$ represent the event that there is at least one accident during day $i$. Write the following events in terms of set operations. Be sure to write a sentence for each part explaining your reasoning in plain English without mentioning set terms.

a. There was at least one accident during the $n$ days.

b. There was no accident during any of the $n$ days.

c. There was at least one accident on each of the $n$ days.

d. There was no accident on at least one of the $n$ days.



3. Residents of a condominium have an automatic
garage door opener that has a row of eight buttons. Each
garage door has been programmed to respond to a particular set of buttons being pushed. 

a. Which example from the chapter 2 slide deck is this example most similar to?

b.  If the condominium houses 250 families, can residents be assured that no two
garage doors will open on the same signal? Yes or no and why or why not.


    


4. The crew of Apollo 17 consisted of two pilots and a geologist. Suppose that NASA had actually trained nine pilots and four geologists. How many possible crews could have been assembled in the following situations? 
For each exercise, write your answer mathematically with reasoning and also calculate it inside a code chunk as you did in quiz section.


a. There is a pilot and a co-pilot? 
 

b. The two pilot positions have identical duties?
